and Michael Heffernan’s chapter in James R. Akerman, The Imperial Map: Cartography and the Mastery of Empire (2008), provide crucial evidence on the birth of mass cartography. Rex Walford, Geography in British Schools, 1850– 2000: Making a World of Difference (2001), is a useful survey on school geography. To finish with, anyone looking for a comprehensive account of the development of the British Empire may begin with the Oxford History of the British Empire and John Darwin, The Empire Project (2009).
